thread.title: Strategic voting may be a factor for many ridings: poll
thread.title_full: Strategic voting may be a factor for many ridings: poll - NEWS 1130

author: Mike Lloyd
title: Strategic voting may be a factor for many ridings: poll
text:
Summary Poll suggests more than a quarter of voters across the country aren't necessarily supporting the party they believe in
VANCOUVER (NEWS 1130) – We are now into the final week of what has been a very long federal election campaign and, as many voters narrow down their choices, there are still some very tight three-way races in many parts of Metro Vancouver.
Strategic voting may be a factor in many ridings with a recent poll suggesting more than a quarter of voters across the country aren’t necessarily supporting the party they believe in, but the party they think has the best chance of defeating the government.
But one high profile Green Party candidate wants voters to think twice on Election Day. “The biggest problem — and I’m immediately going to talk about the elephant in the room here — is strategic voting,” says Claire Martin, who is running in the riding of North Vancouver.
“I just keep telling people to remember, at the end of the day, you are voting for an MP to represent you. So keep the big picture in view but also remember this is about our home, our backyard. Do what gives you the strongest voice and what will make you feel good about your vote,” she tells NEWS 1130 .
Political experts point out there is significant support for the Green Party in some areas, but worries about vote splitting will hurt the party’s election results.
“The consensus is that the Greens might pick up a seat or two here or there, they will hold Elizabeth May’s seat (in Saanich-Gulf Islands) and they might pick up Victoria,” says UBC political science professor Max Cameron. “However my hunch is that while there is support for the Green Party — under other electoral rules thy might do quite well — there is this ongoing concern about splitting the vote.”
